topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/539822686368720badfe0500#post_539822686368720badfe0500
[bq="Whatevs"]"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/539821706368720bef910600#post_539821706368720bef910600
I didn't say they were. I simply mean that Might For Right is a spiritual ideal.

In fact, I'm of the opinion that relative to nearly every powerful religion Christianity is pretty much one of the better ones.

Even its great "crimes" of the past are mostly based on mythical ahistorical retellings in our media (meaning movies and shows) and certainly no worse than the times in general were.
But really that has more to do with the fact that our popular conception of the Dark Ages in Europe is pretty incorrect based on the best evidence we have.
Listverse has a great little thing on the Middle Ages (top 10 myths or something) that SeraphimDawn linked a while ago.[/bq]

I wouldn't call Christianity the better faith over anything. There were about twenty crusades of significant importance called throughout the middle ages and into the high/late Middle Ages by the Catholic See against numerous groups across Europe and Africa; Muslims, Pagans, other Christians that didn't agree. Like wise, their "treatment of alternate ideologies":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catharism#Suppression wasn't as grand, as compared to Islam where at least a number of schools within the two major branches came and went as they pleased. During the crusades even, a vast majority of the native Jewish population was massacred in Jerusalem, along with some Christian minorities that lived there.

"And fundamentalist activity hasn't stopped today.":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_terrorism
topics.author: 4fe4bf947f123b175b000001

"@AaronMk":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53989afa6368720647450200#post_53989afa6368720647450200
Well what period do you mean?

Because I'm aware the idea of Saladin being open to other religions is probably untrue.
topics.author: 4fe16df67f123b13e400003f

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53989db76368722b229f0200#post_53989db76368722b229f0200

For many centuries the Jews and Christians were accepted in Muslim society. "There was in fact a golden age in Jewish culture":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_age_of_Jewish_culture_in_the_Iberian_Peninsula in Iberia under the Moorish Sultans of Al-Andalus. And the forceful conversion and the end of the Golden Age after the reign of Abd-ar-Rahman the Jews still found shelter in the rest of the Islamic world, since the persecution that followed was more-or-less an isolated incident and typical of Iberia during that time.

Saladin's reputation for tolerance goes to when he was "Vizier of Egypt":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saladin_in_Egypt#Social where the Coptic Christians and Jews of Egyptian society retained their jobs and status in Egyptian society. The legend of his tolerance goes further till when he took Jerusalem. "He allowed the holy sites to be visited by Christians and the Holy Sepulcher remained in Christian hands":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(1187)#Surrender_of_Jerusalem and many of the captives he promised to sell to slavery if a ransom was not paid were released regardless, or he paid a part of the ransom himself, or discounted the ransom; the rest were allowed safe passage to the County of Tripoli where they had to figure out how to get home, while being denied access by the Crusader holdouts.
topics.author: 4fe4bf947f123b175b000001
